resource.chars:
* Justice seems to have been hardly done to Chamisso 
as the <s>[text?]<\s> first promulgator of the theory of the “Alternation of Generation”
He says at p.10 “Qua seposita (Salpa bicorni) <u>alternationem generationum <\u>
legem esse ut posuimus genericam, omnibus communem 
speciebus observationibus innititur “ and at p.3
“Talis speciei metamorphosis generationibus in 
Salpis duobus successivis perspicitur, <u>forma per 
generationes <s>[text?]<\s> (nequaquam in prole seu 
individuo) mutata <\u>
Verum enim vero qua lege prolis salparum, ut 
animal ab ovo, imago a larva, inter se differunt 
parum elucet “
Subsequent writers seem not to have done
much more <s>than<\s> in reality than bring new 
cases under the law here so clearly expressed  - and 
they do not always seem to have kept so clearly 
in mind the modest renunciation of any 
claim on the part of the theory to be an <u>explanation <\u> of the facts,
contained in the last paragraph -
Finally it must not be forgotten that though Chamisso 
was the first promulgator of the “Alternation” he expressly 
(with a candour impossible to be too much commended) gives the 
cudis of the conception to his companion Eschscholz “generationis 
Salparum primus et perspicax fuit indagator amicissimus Escscholz” p.9 & again in
the preface to the second fasciculum of his observations.
